Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Design, Construction and Characterization of Metabolite Valves

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0954986
Prather
The proposed work will result in the development of experimental tools to control glucose flux. The Glucose Valve will explore a new paradigm for biochemical production that allows the decoupling of biomass growth and metabolite production in the same way that inducible promoters have done for recombinant protein production. The Valves are intended to facilitate the metabolic engineering of biosynthetic pathways for the production of a variety of organic compounds in microbial chemical factories. The proposal incorporates both fundamental research and educational initiatives. Mathematical models to describe and predict the behavior of the Glucose Valves will also be developed, which should facilitate the extension of this experimental device to other metabolites and organisms. Undergraduate students will be educated in both the classroom and the laboratory, with course materials being made available through the OpenCourseWare portal at MIT. Additionally, a proposed "What-I-Do" Initiative seeks to introduce school age children to science- and engineering-intensive careers through a series of interviews of professionals working in representative STEM fields.

Intellectual merit: This research project was centered on the development of experimental tools to control the flow of metabolites for engineered biosynthetic pathways.  It was motivated by the limitations of traditional metabolic engineering, in which competing reactions are often completely eliminated to avoid losing metabolites to unwanted by-products.  However, when the competing reactions are essential for growth, this traditional approach is no longer an option.  We thus decided to create “metabolic valves” in order to divert substrates from biomass synthesis towards product formation in a controlled manner.  The designed system is analogous to the use of inducible promoters to decouple growth and product formation for recombinant protein synthesis.  The goal was to produce an operational mode in which a “biomass-generating” phase is initially favored to boost the biocatalytic potential, but then is subsequently down-regulated in favor of a “product-generating” phase.  We first demonstrated this concept with a focus on glucose consumption.  E. coli cells were engineered to alter glucose uptake so that the conversion of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate could be used as a control point to construct the valve.  Our results showed that product yields could be increased between 20% and 100%, with high titers achieved of a model compound.  We also explored multiple methods to implement the valve and uncovered important limitations for growth-coupled enzymes.  We next extended this system to a strain in which the native glucose transport system was intact (i.e., coupled to glucose-6-phosphate formation) in order to boost the yield of both an intermediate and the final product in a previously constructed glucaric acid pathway.  A new architecture was employed for these valves, resulting in increases in both product titer and yield of up to 5-fold over the wild-type baseline strain.  This work made significant contributions to the area of “dynamic metabolic engineering,”  illustrating core principles and applications of this exciting new approach.
